author: Kolkata Bureau
text:
Even as the much-debated Left-Congress tie-up in West Bengal received support from majority of the State Committee members of the Communist Party of India-Marxist (CPI-M), a section of leaders strongly opposed the idea.

In the two-day State Committee meeting that concluded on Saturday here, party leaders who opposed the alliance with the Congress were vastly outnumbered by those in favour of such a tie-up.

“In the meeting, 16 of 80 members of the State Committee strongly opposed any tie-up with the Congress as it will be in violation of the political-tactical line adopted at the 21st Party Congress,” a senior CPI(M) leader who opposed the alliance told The Hindu .

“Countering those who favoured the alliance, the anti-alliance group subtly asked whether the accepted political-tactical line of the party should be scrapped,” the leader said.

At the party congress last year, the CPI(M) agreed to “preclude having any understanding or electoral alliance with the Congress.”

Those who opposed the alliance with the Congress are Amal Halder, Gouranga Chatterjee, Achinta Mallik from Bardhaman district, Mriganka Bhattacharya, Muzaffar Hussain, Anisur Rehman from Murshidabad, Biplab Mazumdar and Dilip Ghosh in Hooghly.

From Kolkata, Kallol Majumdar, Niranjan Chatterjee, Salil Acharaya, Mitali Kumar, Pranab Chattopadhyay and Rabin Rai were against the tie-up.

Anti-alliance group cited political-tactical line adopted at party congress
title: Bengal CPI(M) divided over tie-up with Congress
